title: STeCa: Step-level Trajectory Calibration for LLM Agent Learning
author: Hanlin Wang (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Jian Wang (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Chak Tou Leong (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Wenjie Li (The Hong Kong Polytechnic University), ...
relevance_why: The concepts of real-time calibration and reinforcement training of agents can be applied to enhance audio processing tasks, particularly in scenarios requiring adaptive decision-making based on feedback.
background: Developing agents that can dynamically adjust their decision-making in long-horizon tasks to mitigate errors in real-time interactions with their environments.
contribution: This paper introduces Step-Level Trajectory Calibration (STeCa) to solve the issue of accumulating suboptimal actions in LLM-based agent learning, achieving significant improvements in task completion success rates.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily focused on behavior cloning and preference learning without real-time calibration capabilities, leading to error accumulation.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work identifies deviated actions during exploration and constructs calibrated trajectories using automated reflection, enabling dynamic corrections during task execution.

key_innovation: Integrates timely calibration of agent actions through a structured framework that combines exploration feedback and LLM-driven reflection.
real_world_impact: The proposed method enhances agent performance in complex tasks, which could improve applications in interactive environments such as robotics and autonomous systems.
limitations: Computational inefficiencies due to reliance on Monte Carlo sampling and potential underutilization of step rewards for broader optimization tasks.

new_terms.calibrated trajectories: **Calibrated trajectories** refer to paths taken by an agent that have been adjusted in real-time to correct deviations from optimal performance based on ongoing feedback.
new_terms.Monte Carlo sampling: **Monte Carlo sampling** is a statistical technique used to estimate numerical results through random sampling, often applied for risk assessment and uncertainty quantification.

open_sourcing: Code and data are available at https://github.com/WangHanLinHenry/STeCa
